verses.text: When the people saw that Moses delayed coming down from the mountain, they gathered around Aaron and said to him, “Get up, make for us gods who will go before us; for this Moses, the man who brought us up out of the land of Egypt – we do not know what has happened to him.”
verses.comment: The Hebrew term 'gods' could mean 'a god'; translated as 'gods' to match the Hebrew plural 'elohim'.

verses.text: And Aaron said to them, “Take off the gold rings that are in the ears of your wives, your sons, and your daughters, and bring them to me.”
verses.comment: Notes 'sons' and 'daughters' to preserve the family context in the original Hebrew.

verses.text: So all the people took off the gold rings that were in their ears and brought them to Aaron.
He took them from their hands, fashioned it with a graving tool, and made it into a molten calf. And they said, “These are your gods, O Israel, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt!”
verses.comment: 'Molten calf' is literal rendering; 'gods' again follows the Hebrew plural.

verses.text: When Aaron saw this, he built an altar before it. And Aaron announced, “Tomorrow will be a feast to the LORD.”
verses.comment: 'LORD' capitalized for the divine name, YHWH.

verses.text: So they got up early the next day, offered burnt offerings, and brought peace offerings. And the people sat down to eat and drink and rose up to play.
verses.comment: 'Rose up to play' may imply revelry or pagan celebration.

verses.text: Then the LORD said to Moses, “Go down at once, for your people, whom you brought up out of the land of Egypt, have corrupted themselves.
verses.comment: The LORD refers to the people as Moses’ own to highlight responsibility.

verses.text: They have quickly turned aside from the way that I commanded them. They have made for themselves a molten calf, have bowed down to it, sacrificed to it, and said, ‘These are your gods, O Israel, who brought you up out of the land of Egypt.’”
And the LORD said to Moses, “I have seen this people, and indeed, it is a stiff-necked people.
verses.comment: 'Stiff-necked' is an idiom meaning stubborn or resistant.

verses.text: Now therefore, let me alone, so that my anger may burn against them and I may consume them. But I will make of you a great nation.”
But Moses pleaded with the LORD his God and said, “O LORD, why does your anger burn against your people, whom you have brought out of the land of Egypt with great power and with a mighty hand?
verses.comment: Moses appeals to God's reputation and past works.

verses.text: Why should the Egyptians say, ‘He brought them out with evil intent, to kill them in the mountains and to wipe them off the face of the earth’? Turn from your burning anger and change your mind about this disaster against your people.
verses.comment: Literal translation of 'change your mind.'

verses.text: Remember Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, your servants, to whom you swore by your own self, saying to them, ‘I will multiply your descendants as the stars of heaven, and all this land that I have promised, I will give to your descendants, and they shall inherit it forever.’”
verses.comment: 'Israel' is Jacob's alternate name in context.

verses.text: So the LORD relented about the disaster that he said he would bring on his people.
verses.comment: 'Relented' as literal for Hebrew 'to change heart/mind.'

verses.text: Then Moses turned and went down from the mountain with the two tablets of the testimony in his hand, tablets written on both sides; on one side and on the other they were written.
verses.comment: 'Testimony' refers to the Ten Commandments.

verses.text: The tablets were the work of God, and the writing was the writing of God, engraved on the tablets.
When Joshua heard the noise of the people as they shouted, he said to Moses, “There is a noise of war in the camp.”
But he said, “It is not the sound of shouting for victory, nor is it the sound of cry for defeat, but the sound of singing that I hear.”
verses.comment: 'Singing' literally means the sound of celebration or revelry.

verses.text: As soon as he came near the camp and saw the calf and the dancing, Moses’ anger burned, and he threw the tablets out of his hands and broke them at the foot of the mountain.
He took the calf which they had made, burned it with fire, ground it to powder, scattered it on the water, and made the Israelites drink it.
verses.comment: Follows sequence of Hebrew verbs as closely as possible.

verses.text: Moses said to Aaron, “What did this people do to you, that you have brought such a great sin upon them?”
Aaron said, “Do not let your anger burn, my lord. You know the people, that they are set on evil.
verses.comment: 'My lord' is respectful address; 'set on evil' is literal.

verses.text: For they said to me, ‘Make us gods who will go before us; as for this Moses, the man who brought us up out of the land of Egypt, we do not know what has happened to him.’
So I said to them, ‘Whoever has any gold, let them take it off.’ So they gave it to me, and I threw it into the fire, and out came this calf!”
verses.comment: Aaron's statement is an excuse; the translation preserves the tone.

verses.text: When Moses saw that the people had broken loose (for Aaron had let them break loose, to the derision of their enemies),
verses.comment: 'Broken loose' means become wild or out of control; 'to the derision of their enemies' is a literal phrase.

verses.text: then Moses stood in the gate of the camp and said, “Whoever is for the LORD, come to me.” Then all the sons of Levi gathered around him.

And he said to them, “This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: ‘Each of you put his sword on his side, and go back and forth from gate to gate throughout the camp, and each of you kill his brother, his friend, and his neighbor.’”
verses.comment: 'Brother, friend, neighbor' retains the shock and directness of Hebrew.

verses.text: The sons of Levi did as Moses commanded, and about three thousand men of the people fell that day.
Then Moses said, “Consecrate yourselves today to the LORD – for every man has been against his son and his brother – so that he may bestow a blessing upon you today.”
verses.comment: 'Consecrate yourselves' is a literal phrasing for setting oneself apart to the Lord.

verses.text: The next day Moses said to the people, “You have committed a great sin. Now I will go up to the LORD; perhaps I can make atonement for your sin.”
verses.comment: 'Atonement' is a key theological term retained from Hebrew 'kaphar'.

verses.text: So Moses returned to the LORD and said, “Oh, this people have sinned a great sin, and have made for themselves gods of gold.
But now, if you will forgive their sin – but if not, please blot me out of your book that you have written.”
verses.comment: Reference to God’s book of life.

verses.text: And the LORD said to Moses, “Whoever has sinned against me, I will blot out of my book.
Now go, lead the people to the place about which I have spoken to you. Look, my angel will go before you. But in the day that I visit, I will punish them for their sin.”
verses.comment: 'My angel' is literal Hebrew; 'in the day I visit' means day of judgment.

verses.text: And the LORD struck the people with a plague because of what they had done with the calf which Aaron made.
verses.comment: 'Plague' as the literal Hebrew word for punishment or affliction.
